p: Binning of metagenomic contigs by coverage profiles is widely used in general metagenomics (Alneberg et al., 2014) and can be used to recover rare bacterial species from metagenomes (Albertsen et al., 2013). In viral metagenomes, coverage profile binning was used to assemble viral genomes across different human gut metagenomes avoiding the use of reference strains (Nielsen et al., 2014) and to verify cross-assemblies of a novel bacteriophage present in 73% of all publicly available gut metagenomes (Dutilh et al., 2014). However, if amplification is applied during metagenome processing, a coverage bias can be introduced to the sequencing data (Karlsson et al., 2013; Rosseel et al., 2013). In such cases, coverage profile binning does not always have the desired effect of linking fragments from the same source (Smits et al., 2014). Therefore, coverage profile binning can be applied in cases in which amplification is unnecessary or the introduction of a coverage bias was excluded.
